subject: AI and future jobs
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread is a battleground between dire predictions of AI-driven job displacement and economic collapse, contrasted with arguments for productivity gains and new job creation. Underlying the debate is significant anxiety about the future for younger generations and a strong undercurrent of distrust towards AI companies and media narratives, with accusations of shilling.
top_quote: Increased productivity =/= increased jobs. Imagine you own a factory with 100 employees who can each make 100 widgets a day for a total of 10,000 widgets. Let's say a new machine is created that allows each employee to make 1000 widgets a day instead... If demand is already saturated and cannot be increased by lowering prices then it makes more sense to simply keep prices high and fire 90 of your employees and hire 10 people to run the machines for a net loss of 80 jobs. You now have 20 employees making the same 10,000 widgets. The idea of technological unemployment ultimately leading to new jobs is a boomer meme from an era when the world was so poor and starved of basic goods that there was essentially unlimited demand as long as you could keep decreasing prices. That era is long over.
image_analysis: The image is a headline titled 'AI Expert Warns 99% of Workers Will Lose Jobs by 2030', providing a stark, doomer-pilled context for the thread's discussion on AI and job displacement.

assets.name: AI
assets.narrative: AI is predicted to eliminate most entry-level jobs and potentially 99% of all jobs by 2030, leading to either UBI or societal collapse, while others claim it will increase productivity and create new job opportunities.

assets.narrative: The sentiment is that jobs, especially entry-level ones, are disappearing due to AI and an 'endless supply of labor,' leading to stagnant wages and potential mass unemployment.

subject: why are crypto dieded?

top_quote: Bull runs grow from seeds. The seed is a new narrative that a small group of users actually think is a big deal. They make 10x. They tell their friends. Their friends make 5x. They tell their friends that there is this actual new thing and people are making a ton of money out of it. So to have a bullrun you need: 1) New narratives that 2) People actually believe in, that 3) Launch at a low enough cap for early users to make money off. The current meta is just mass VC extraction events launching down-only stale narratives (another L1 lmao) at $10B FDV. No retail makes any money so there is no group of organic shills, so there is no momentum.

subject: Options Snapshot: AI Doom & Stock Plays
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread centers on using options open interest and put/call ratios to gauge market sentiment for various stocks, highlighting the underlying bearishness for Oracle and the broader AI sector due to doubts about OpenAI's financial stability. The discussion reflects a community attempting to derive actionable trading insights from these metrics, mixed with typical /biz/ humor and skepticism.
top_quote: >>61477942 WHAT is neutral? you don't have any labels retard >>61474291 This chart basically shows how much money is in puts and calls for each expiration. The bars are the notional value of all outstanding puts and calls, and the dots are the dollar weighted put call ratio (> 1.5 is bearish, < 0.5 is bullish). Put call ratio is just one signal out of many. Saying the chart is neutral is just saying this one particular signal is neutral. If you're investing, pay attention to fundamentals. If you're trading, look for a confluence of signals. The weakness of pcr is that it doesn't tell you who own what options. It's technically possible to have a low pcr, but everyone's in bear call spreads, meaning the signal is bullish while actual sentiment is bearish. In reality, extreme imbalances like that would blow out IV or premiums on one side, so they would be corrected by supply and demand. So the assumption is that a high or low pcr does actually gauge sentiment. But you still ought to look at other signals.
image_analysis: The chart for Oracle (ORCL) on 2025-12-11 displays a strong bearish sentiment, with most dollar-weighted put/call ratios (orange dots) significantly above 1.5 and a notable dominance of put notional value (orange bars below zero) over call notional value (blue bars above zero) across various expirations.

subject: Does anyone here own their own business? Is it worth it to buy an established business, or is it easy to buy your own inventory and rent your own space and do something like a liquor store?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread discusses the viability of starting a small retail business, specifically a liquor store, versus acquiring an established one, highlighting the significant challenges of low liquidity, high overhead, and fierce competition from large-scale retailers. It emphasizes the need for extensive due diligence when purchasing an existing business and the importance of persistence in entrepreneurship, despite the inherent risks.
top_quote:
That question makes no sense at all, OP but your picture made me laugh
While there are exceptions, retail business is by and large a low-liquidity operation where you need to dedicate a lot of space and square footage to dead stock and hope it moves enough product to keep the lights on and pay the taxes, maintenance, and rent on the building. This is why most surviving retailers like Walmart and Target operate at massive scale.
